newsitem.title: USA: Chicago news anchors irked by talk-show commentator.
newsitem.headline: Chicago news anchors irked by talk-show commentator.

text.p: A threatened revolt by a Chicago news anchor team over their NBC-TV station's plan to air commentaries by tabloid TV talk-show host Jerry Springer was chided in a newspaper editorial Tuesday.

The generally well-respected news anchors, Carol Marin and Ron Magers, told local media writers their public would be ill-served by Springer's opinions and threatened to walk off the set when he is introduced on Monday night's broadcast.
"Their public protest would make them look more like prima donnas than the talented journalists they are," the Chicago Sun-Times wrote in Tuesday's editorial.

"By now, viewers are as familiar with the trashy topics Springer dishes up as they are with Marin and Magers' first-class delivery of breaking news stories ... (Viewers) are more than able to pull their own plugs," the paper said.

For his part, the 53-year-old Springer, a former news anchor and mayor of Cincinnati, Ohio, told the Sun-Times of the erupting controversy: "What the hell? It's only reading a prompter. I mean, they make it seem like it's journalism."

Before beginning his trashy, often tongue-in-cheek daytime talk-show six years ago, Springer was a top news anchor, commentator and managing editor in Cincinnati until 1993. Before that, he was elected Cincinnati mayor in 1977 at the young age of 33.
The local NBC-TV station did not respond to requests for comment. The station is owned by the network, a unit of General Electric Co.
